metadata.case_name: Appellant (Elected Candidate from Mahasamund) v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: The appellant was elected to the House of the People from the Mahasamund parliamentary constituency in the State of Madhya Pradesh in the third general elections.
The respondents were the other contesting candidates.

Respondent No. 1 filed an election petition before the Election Commission of India under sections 80 and 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 for setting aside the election of the appellant and it was duly referred to the Election Tribunal.
The Election Tribunal, by its order dated January 5, 1963, dismissed the election petition.
On February 11, 1963, the first respondent preferred an appeal against the said order of the Election Tribunal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur.

Under sub-section (3) of section 116A of the Representation of the People Act, every appeal under Chapter IVA shall be preferred within a period of thirty days from the date of the order of the Tribunal under section 98 or section 99 thereof.
Admittedly, the appeal was filed more than 30 days from the said order.
If the time requisite for obtaining a copy of the order of the Tribunal was excluded, the appeal was filed within 30 days.
The appellant contended before the High Court that respondent 1 was not entitled in law to exclude the time so taken by him in obtaining a copy of the order of the Tribunal.

The High Court rejected the plea on limitation and held that the appellant had committed two acts of corrupt practice as defined by section 123(4) of the Act and declared the election of the appellant void.
The present appeal has been preferred by the appellant against the said order of the High Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether for the purpose of computing the period of 30 days prescribed under section 116A(3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, the provisions of section 12 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908 can be invoked via section 29(2) thereof.
Whether the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is a special law prescribing a period of limitation different from that in the First Schedule to the Limitation Act for appeals under section 116A.
Construction of Article 156 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act: whether it applies to appeals under section 116A where procedure is governed by the Code of Civil Procedure.
Inter-relation between the two limbs of section 29(2) of the Limitation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 29(2) Limitation Act applies only where the First Schedule prescribes a period for the identical appeal and the special law prescribes a different period; since no provision in First Schedule for appeal under s.116A RPA, s.29(2) inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 29(2) Limitation Act; dissenting view of Raghubar Dayal J. in Sehat Ali Khan

petitioner_arguments.text: Article 156 Limitation Act applies only to appeals where right conferred by CPC, not where procedure only governed by CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 156 Limitation Act; decisions on 'under' in criminal appeals

petitioner_arguments.text: The two limbs of s.29(2) are cumulative; second limb depends on first, so provisions of cl.(a) not attracted without satisfying opening condition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 29(2) Limitation Act; Raghubar Dayal J. dissent

petitioner_arguments.text: Order under s.98 RPA is neither decree, judgment nor order as defined in CPC for s.12(2) Limitation Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 12(2) Limitation Act; s.2 CPC definitions

respondent_arguments.text: Article 156 applies as appeal under s.116A is governed by CPC procedure, akin to Letters Patent appeals excepted in Art.151.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 156 Limitation Act; Aga Mohd. Hamdani v. Cohen; Ramasami Pillai v. Deputy Collector

respondent_arguments.text: Even if no identical provision in First Schedule, special law prescribes different period (30 days vs. no limit or 90 days), satisfying s.29(2).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 29(2) Limitation Act; Canara Bank Ltd. v. Warden Insurance Co.

respondent_arguments.text: Second limb of s.29(2) independent, applies to any period prescribed by special law.

court_reasoning.text: RPA is special law prescribing different limitation period; First Schedule Art.156 covers appeals governed by CPC procedure even if right not conferred by CPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consistent High Court view upheld; legislative practice relies on it.

court_reasoning.text: Even on narrow view, s.116A(2) RPA fictions appeal as from original decree under CPC, so Art.156 applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.116A(2) equates powers, jurisdiction, procedure to CPC appeal.

court_reasoning.text: Two limbs of s.29(2) integrated; second limb subject to first part's condition; first part alone incomplete without attracting computation provisions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Avoids anomaly; Raghubar Dayal J. view approved by Ayyangar J.

court_reasoning.text: Subba Rao J.: Second limb independent; 'any' indicates generality; no anomaly in differential application of sections.
Order under s.98 RPA is judgment and order attracting s.12(2); Tribunal follows CPC procedure per s.90 RPA.

holdings.text: Section 29(2) Limitation Act applies to appeals under s.116A RPA; s.12(2) available to exclude time for copy.
Art.156 Limitation Act applies to appeals governed by CPC procedure.
Appeal to High Court was within time.

precedents_cited.case_name: Canara Bank Ltd., Bombay v. The Warden Insurance Co. Ltd., Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Even if no provision in First Schedule for identical appeal, special law prescribes different period satisfying s.29(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Smt. Kaushaliya
precedents_cited.relevance: Upholds Bombay view in Canara Bank.
Art.156 applies to appeals governed by CPC procedure though right under special law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramasami Pillai v. Deputy Collector of Madura
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.156 for Land Acquisition Act appeals under CPC procedure.
Legislative practice assumes Art.156 for special law appeals under CPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sehat Ali Khan v. Abdul Qavi Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench on limbs of s.29(2); majority vs dissent discussed.
s.29(2) applies even where no Limitation Act period.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes 30-day limit for appeals from Tribunal orders; High Court follows CPC procedure as if civil appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: s.29(2) applies provisions to special law periods; s.12 excludes time for copy in computing appeal period.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure, definitions of decree/judgment/order; governs RPA appeals.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that section 12(2) of the Limitation Act applies via section 29(2) to compute the 30-day period under section 116A(3) RPA, excluding time for obtaining copy of Tribunal order. High Court order allowing appeal and voiding election affirmed; merits not examined as not argued.

key_quotes.text: "The natural meaning of an appeal under the Civil Procedure Code appears to us to be an appeal governed by the Code of Civil Procedure so far as procedure is concerned."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Construction of Art.156 from Aga Hamdani, adopted by SC.

key_quotes.text: "If the first Schedule to the Limitation Act omits laying down any period of limitation for a particular appeal and the special law provides a period of limitation, then to that extent the special law is different from the Limitation Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Chagla CJ in Canara Bank, key to s.29(2) where no Schedule period.

key_quotes.text: "We agree that the appeal fails and we direct that it be dismissed with costs."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Unanimous final holding by Ayyangar J.
